# Task

Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.



# Special Instructions

None.

```julia
using Dates

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[!, :ym] = map(x -> string(Dates.year(x)) * string(Dates.month(x)), df.dt)
end
```

This function uses the `map` function to apply a transformation to each element of the `dt` column. The transformation itself is a lambda expression that extracts the year and month from each date-time object using the `Dates.year` and `Dates.month` functions, then concatenates them together as a string in the desired format. Finally, it creates a new column `ym` in the DataFrame with the result.

The `map` function returns an array of the transformed values, which is then assigned to the new column using the `setindex!` function (abbreviated as `[:!, :ym]`). This is necessary because we are creating a new column in place; if you were just returning a modified copy of the DataFrame, you wouldn't need the `!`.

The `string` function is used to convert the year and month numbers into strings, which are then concatenated with the `*` operator. The result is a string in the format "yyyymm", which is what we want for the new column.

Remember to call this function on your DataFrame:

```julia
df = your_existing_dataframe  # Replace with your actual data frame
add_yearmonth(df)
```

This will modify the `df` in place by adding a new column named "ym".
